verses.text: Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge, but one who hates correction is foolish.
verses.comment: The original Hebrew term rendered 'foolish' literally means 'stupid animal.' Loving discipline points to a heart open to instruction—a theme found throughout wisdom literature.

verses.text: A good man obtains favor from the LORD, but a schemer He will condemn.
verses.comment: 'Favor' reflects the concept of divine blessing. Faithful living brings affirmation from God, while devious behavior leads to divine disapproval.

verses.text: No one is established by wickedness, but the righteous cannot be uprooted.
verses.comment: Stability is a theme, comparing the fleeting security of evil to the enduring nature of the righteous. See Jesus' imagery of the house built upon rock (Matthew 7:24-25).

verses.text: An excellent wife is the crown of her husband, but she who brings shame is like decay in his bones.
verses.comment: The language reflects the profound influence of a virtuous spouse. The metaphor of a 'crown' signifies honor and joy.

verses.text: The thoughts of the righteous are just, but the counsels of the wicked are deceitful.
verses.comment: God values not just deeds, but even one's internal thoughts (cf. Matthew 5:21-22).

verses.text: The words of the wicked lie in wait for blood, but the speech of the upright rescues them.
verses.comment: Speech has power—used for evil, it brings harm; used for good, it delivers. Christ is the ultimate ‘Word’ who brings life (John 1:1-4).

verses.text: The wicked are overthrown and are no more, but the house of the righteous will stand.
verses.comment: Imagery of ‘the house of the righteous’ echoes the promise of spiritual legacy and enduring faith.

verses.text: A man is praised according to his wisdom, but one with a twisted mind is despised.
verses.comment: Human dignity is connected to moral character. Wisdom aligns a person with God's order, folly brings shame.

verses.text: Better to be of humble position and have a servant, than to pretend to be important, yet lack bread.
verses.comment: Genuine humility and honest provision are valued over empty appearances.

verses.text: The righteous care for the life of their animals, but the compassion of the wicked is cruel.
verses.comment: God's concern extends to all creation (see Psalm 145:9). The spiritual life brings care for even the lowliest.

verses.text: Whoever works his land will have plenty of bread, but he who chases empty pursuits lacks sense.
verses.comment: 'Empty pursuits' or ‘worthless pursuits’ warn against idleness and foolish ambitions.

verses.text: The wicked desire the spoil of evildoers, but the root of the righteous bears fruit.
verses.comment: Righteous living brings life and increase, while envy of the wicked leads nowhere. The 'root' imagery recalls Jesus as the true root and vine (John 15:5).

verses.text: By the sin of his lips a wicked man is trapped, but the righteous escape from trouble.
verses.comment: Speech's effect is double-edged; truthful lips allow freedom, but lies ensnare the speaker.

verses.text: From the fruit of his mouth a person is filled with good things, and the work of a man's hands comes back to him.
verses.comment: Words and deeds are both seeds that bear fruit—foundational for later teachings about the final judgment (Matthew 12:36-37).

verses.text: The way of a fool is right in his own eyes, but a wise man listens to advice.
verses.comment: Humility before counsel is key to wisdom, echoing the spiritual necessity of listening to God’s messengers and tradition.

verses.text: A fool’s anger is known at once, but a prudent man overlooks an insult.
verses.comment: Wisdom is seen in patience and control of one's emotions.

verses.text: Whoever speaks the truth gives honest testimony, but a false witness utters deceit.
verses.comment: Truthfulness in speech is highlighted, reinforcing the commandment to not bear false witness.

verses.text: There is one whose rash words are like sword thrusts, but the tongue of the wise brings healing.
verses.comment: Speech can wound or heal—recall that Jesus is described as the 'Word' that heals and saves.

verses.text: Truthful lips endure forever, but a lying tongue lasts only a moment.
verses.comment: Righteousness and truth have eternal value, a theme deepened in the New Testament teachings.

verses.text: Deceit is in the heart of those who plot evil, but those who promote peace have joy.
verses.comment: Echoes the beatitude—'Blessed are the peacemakers.'

verses.text: No disaster will overcome the righteous, but the wicked are filled with trouble.
verses.comment: Righteousness is no guarantee of earthly ease, but ultimately means God’s protection and providence.

verses.text: Lying lips are an abomination to the LORD, but those who act faithfully are His delight.
verses.comment: 'Abomination' reflects the Hebrew term for something strongly detested by God, indicating the seriousness of truthfulness.

verses.text: A prudent man conceals knowledge, but the heart of fools proclaims folly.
verses.comment: Discretion is a trait of the wise; not all knowledge must be spoken.

verses.text: The hand of the diligent will rule, but slackness leads to forced labor.
verses.comment: Work, diligence, and stewardship are consistently praised; spiritual discipline is necessary to attain lasting reward.

verses.text: Anxiety weighs down a person’s heart, but a good word makes it glad.
verses.comment: Affirming the healing power of speech. Encouragement lifts burdens, pointing to Christ as the bringer of peace.

verses.text: The righteous choose their friends carefully, but the way of the wicked leads them astray.
verses.comment: Companions influence character. The importance of discernment in fellowship points to the spiritual community.

verses.text: Whoever is lazy does not roast his prey, but the diligent gain precious wealth.
verses.comment: Faith and effort must be joined for blessing. Echoes the spiritual necessity of participating in grace.

verses.text: In the path of righteousness is life, and in its pathway there is no death.
verses.comment: The final verse directs to the promise of eternal life through righteousness, in both literal and spiritual senses. This finds its fullness in Christ who is the way, the truth, and the life.
